import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd

df1=pd.read_csv('../input/international-airline-passengers/international-airline-passengers.csv', index_col='Month', parse_dates=True)
df1.index_freq= 'MS'
df2=pd.read_csv('../input/daily-total-female-births-in-california-1959/daily-total-female-births-CA.csv',index_col='date', parse_dates=True)
df2.index_freq= 'D'

df1.plot() # Has a seasonal and trend component "non_stationary"
df2.plot() # Has no trend o
source.ce5556b6:
from pandas.plotting import lag_plot
lag_plot(df1['International airline passengers: monthly totals in thousands. Jan 49 ? Dec 60']) #Non stationary cause it has a strong correlation between 2 axis
source.0b6838aa:
from statsmodels.graphics.tsaplots import plot_acf, plot_pacf
plot_acf(df1,lags=40);
source.13c7ff1f: plot_pacf(df2,lags=40,title='daily female births'); #pacf work will with stationary data

## In this note book I will explain :

................................................................................................................

## - Autocorrelation function plot & Partial Autocorrelation function plot:

### Auto correlation : is the correlation of the series with itself, shifted by x time units. It also ansewring the question "How correlated are today's sales to yesterday's sales?"
![](https://scontent.faly3-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/120425972_816195005858782_724789896890723027_o.jpg?_nc_cat=105&_nc_sid=730e14&_nc_eui2=AeGe0DTlncO5bQZYVik7jrCdNxxWQ6aWbgQ3HFZDppZuBMK5IE05tQJhxoHreNTeYy4eh7zJoFuF8-ZqkG_GvmpH&_nc_ohc=zdwd3RR87NsAX81OK8z&_nc_ht=scontent.faly3-1.fna&oh=e6ad32fd20f634c31b316441b61b4cd7&oe=5F9A2B08)
### As we see,
### 1- We plot the autocorrelation 0.8 between day i-1 and itself
### 2- We plot autocorrelation and the shift 0.8
### 3- Reapeat these steps for day i-2, day i-3, day i-4...
![](https://scontent.faly3-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/120581290_816195012525448_2761107945396776452_o.jpg?_nc_cat=100&_nc_sid=730e14&_nc_eui2=AeHXMn-3OQ9OnJhYq_IG5sdmSxI_30pZkKtLEj_fSlmQq1vaY_ZoeeanZD_QZrMXK85D6ifdOk5v85l6u8E72x2n&_nc_ohc=rFueS_GZt9UAX-vqJd5&_nc_ht=scontent.faly3-1.fna&oh=0a421a88704213bb68652e5dd1df7af4&oe=5F984EE2)
source.729ec343:
### There are 2 tyeps of correlation :
![](https://scontent.faly3-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/120489613_816195122525437_8369457150931730563_o.jpg?_nc_cat=100&_nc_sid=730e14&_nc_eui2=AeErakhU-1SkLt4h21Y5VelBRQr3c70ywt9FCvdzvTLC3_KHd1gijL4SihiAQahJv5fQan9KYHf39Vaigshl-2G3&_nc_ohc=6Yqr_o3HKbsAX__dNxx&_nc_ht=scontent.faly3-1.fna&oh=35bd5fb6095d03b82b453b80c117b0ae&oe=5F99E898)

### 1- Gradual correlation : Has a pattern of high correlation that has repeated aovr time period
### 2- Sharp Drop-off : Has high correlation between day & the day before.

source.50ca5e63:
## Partial autocorrelation: 
### 1- We take the residuals between the auto correlation of the day and plot it against the day.
### Residuals is the errors that can't be explained by the linear model

![](https://scontent.faly3-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/120442397_816195032525446_2189313566576623281_n.jpg?_nc_cat=107&_nc_sid=730e14&_nc_eui2=AeF6Y2BuT-zv3-uDXP81LApHEk0BZVbazGESTQFlVtrMYZ14Hjd8UbnfLPmphbEbhKWxGqdrJ47Q3hM9r1Nr_mR2&_nc_ohc=8Xxy1bwIuHgAX-JlcQC&_nc_ht=scontent.faly3-1.fna&oh=145cca4f23f7880f4bf3b9d222c0cd4f&oe=5F98C9BE)
 
![](https://scontent.faly3-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/120520264_816195055858777_8429280964130852449_o.jpg?_nc_cat=102&_nc_sid=730e14&_nc_eui2=AeE_SnGj-yMSbJolJ86HOU22roPvkwoU2piug--TChTamO7XpO6yHiFa2mrOjvklRwNrJu5YE6FrQD3i8YtassJK&_nc_ohc=0Ld873rntekAX8-K1l3&_nc_ht=scontent.faly3-1.fna&oh=6ffedcfdb40bdf7a98a284e6837114f3&oe=5F984429) 
  ### 2- Then we repeat the step for dayi-2, dayi-3, dayi-4... and plot it against the day after
![](https://scontent.faly3-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/120354878_816195262525423_7899526926829987221_o.jpg?_nc_cat=111&_nc_sid=730e14&_nc_eui2=AeHWvnwFYltQkv_B7EZtrYPQiIHcTAGTuR-IgdxMAZO5H09_QdlyAQmWFdKnvRN2SBhRWwHZ4z4zk2OKNYslzL-B&_nc_ohc=1hYWBoGwKVwAX93EPSL&_nc_ht=scontent.faly3-1.fna&oh=570cce9dbcc4c4491ce259460f693e1a&oe=5F98FBEF) 
### 3- After we plot the dayi-1 & dayi-2 , we take the risidual by drawing a line and repeat the process
![](https://scontent.faly3-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/120402295_816195289192087_6702217315388247506_n.jpg?_nc_cat=105&_nc_sid=730e14&_nc_eui2=AeGEqWcFC5-evNpqbdRslBrqbHg7CyEnz8dseDsLISfPx2yKXc0VthVtgJqOssSobj5UjMRH2hA4HcnQyynMR1xq&_nc_ohc=rx0xCfXVUeUAX_ibjzC&_nc_ht=scontent.faly3-1.fna&oh=14459355a73c893856a23da3ce3eb0b1&oe=5F97180D)
 
 ## We can use ACF & PACF to determine ARIMA forecasting component
